title: Ticket #2575: Limit c-gahp's time connected to the schedd
description:
The c-gahp should not spend more than a couple seconds at a time connected to a schedd. When the c-gahp is used to submit and monitor thousands of jobs, it can end up being connected to the schedd for 10 seconds at a time or more. During this time, the schedd won't talk to other clients. If several c-gahps are talking to a schedd, some of them will start timing out trying to connect. See ticket #2279 for a concrete example of this occurring.

Having the schedd support multiple client connections and transactions is the best long-term solution, but would be a fair amount of work. A faster short-term solution is to have the c-gahp limit how many operations it does per connection. This would reduce the time for clients to get a response from the schedd. Multiple c-gahps would effectively round-robin their interactions with the schedd at a coarse granularity.

The additional connections will add some overhead, which may hurt the schedd's scalability. We'll need to measure this.

Milestones

  • Plan changes to c-gahp, including prevention of command starvation
  • Reproduce OSG grid school Condor-C failures
  • Add connection-time limiting code to c-gahp
  • Measure effects of connection-time limiting code
remarks:
2012-Jun-17 20:34:49 by bbockelm:
Here's a nice little script (must be run as root) to insert a 200ms one-way delay to IP 129.93.239.129 (my test schedd) from a test submit host: 

tc qdisc add dev eth0 handle 1: root htb
tc class add dev eth0 parent 1: classid 1:1 htb rate 1000Mbps
tc class add dev eth0 parent 1:1 classid 1:11 htb rate 500Mbps
tc class add dev eth0 parent 1:1 classid 1:12 htb rate 500Mbps
tc qdisc add dev eth0 parent 1:11 handle 10: netem delay 200ms
tc filter add dev eth0 protocol ip prio 1 u32 match ip dst 129.93.239.129 flowid 1:11

It beats trying to find a really, really long network cord.

In tests, with this patch, I confirmed that the stage in/out is non-blocking on the schedd. We could probably move the timeouts to only cover only when in the qmgmt interface. At 200ms (one-way delay), the schedd can submit one job a second. With the one second sleep between connections, we could probably submit 50 jobs a minute from a single thread (but not really, because it'll mix in staging too). That's 3,000 jobs an hour - about 3x the rate necessary to keep the busiest OSG CE filled. At 50ms (one-way delay), the schedd can submit three jobs a second.

2012-Jul-18 13:52:33 by jfrey:
CODE REVIEW

The patch looks pretty good. There are some additional changes I'd want to see done, which I could work on. I wouldn't apply it to Condor 7.8.x in its current form, but it could go into master.

  • Stage-out commands aren't skipped when the schedd interaction time has elapsed.

  • We still connect to the schedd with ConnectQ() when the interaction time has elapsed, then immediately disconnect. We should avoid that connection.

  • When using SetAttribute_NoAck, we should be more careful in handling failures. The schedd closes the connection when a SetAttribute fails with NoAck. This will cause all subsequent commands to the schedd to fail, leading to gahp commands for unrelated jobs to fail. We should retry the commands for those other jobs.

  • The NoAck flag was introduced in Condor 7.5.3. Do we need to maintain compatibility with older versions?

2012-Jul-19 10:02:25 by bbockelm:
Hi Jaime,

  1. Stageout commands are purposely not skipped when the timeout is hit. They don't appear to exclusively use the schedd in my tests. I.e., I can have a client do "condor_q" at the same time stageout is going. (Perhaps I'm just not using large-enough stage-in files?)
  2. I'll let you do the follow-up optimization for ConnectQ/DisconnectQ.
  3. The comments about NoAck are correct, but I think that's for follow-up work. This patch preserves the existing behavior on an error, right?
  4. I discussed this with Dan; I don't think we need to preserve backward-compatibility here, as performance would be so miserable without NoAck.

Why not commit to 7.8? My opinion is that this is a pretty low-risk bugfix. It'd really hurt our ability to rollout Condor-CE if we had to wait for the pilot factories to switch to Condor 7.10.0 (as the CMS ones don't want to do dev releases).

Thanks for the review,

Brian

2012-Aug-27 16:02:03 by jfrey:
Finally getting back to this ticket...

The only time the c-gahp is connected to the schedd for longer than one call into the DCSchedd object is the section between ConnectQ() and DisconnectQ(). Starting the schedd conneciton time earlier than the ConnectQ() buys us nothing.

I need to do some testing, but the use of the NoAck flag may cause the c-gahp to endlessly retry some commands in some situations (job ad disappears from the remote queue unexpectedly). That should be easy to fix if it is a problem.
attachments:
• cgahp_scaling.patch 3775 bytes added by bbockelm on 2012-Jun-17 14:45:24 UTC.
    Here's a simple, minimal fix.

    Status updates and submits (which happen in a separate transaction regardless) are changed to set NoAck for attribute updates. If one attribute update fails, then the whole command will fail: this is the same behavior as before, except the failure isn't discovered until the commit is attempted (instead of when the attribute is set).

    I also implement a simple time-limiting mechanism: if it has been more than 5 seconds since the client started interacting with the schedd, it will break out of the loops and reconnect to the schedd 1 second later.

    Right now, the QMGMT_TIMEOUT is hard-coded to 15 seconds. I would propose making that a parameter and increasing it to 50 seconds: this would allow 10 active clients to actively interact at once.

    Commands are processed in a FIFO by command type (i.e., all staging requests are done before submit requests). I actually kind of like the prioritization as-is.

    Are file transfers non-blocking? If they aren't, I think the only place where we now block the schedd is in the submit and status updates. If they do block the schedd, we might be in Big Trouble.
